title: Lab to determine g by rolling a sphere off a table

content.question:

A group of students are going to perform an experiment to determine the magnitude of acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown. The setup includes a device that gives an angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which can be varied, to a solid sphere with mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The solid sphere rolls to the right in the direction of motion on the top of a horizontal table without slipping and with angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The table has length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is height <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the ground. The students are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The table has length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is height <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the ground. The students are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown. <math alttext="I sub sphere, equals two fifths M R squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi><mi>h</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure to be used to determine the magnitude of acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the magnitude of acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the magnitude of acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Another group of students perform the same experiment, but they use hollow spheres of the same diameter and mass as the solid spheres used by the other group. The new group of students follow the same procedure and analysis as described in part (b) through part (d) without adjusting for the difference in the spheres. Will the calculated magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> determined using the hollow sphere be greater than, less than, or equal to the magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> obtained in the experiment with the solid sphere?
